description:
Alterisphingorhabdus coralli is a species of marine microalgae belonging to the phylum Haptophyta. It is a unicellular, photosynthetic organism that is found in various marine environments, particularly in coral reef ecosystems.

The cells of Alterisphingorhabdus coralli are typically small, ranging from 5 to 10 micrometers in diameter. They possess a distinctive cell wall composed of organic scales or plates, which are a characteristic feature of haptophyte algae. The cells have a single chloroplast, which contains chlorophyll and other photosynthetic pigments, allowing the organism to perform photosynthesis.

Alterisphingorhabdus coralli is known to play a role in the ecology of coral reef systems, where it can be found as part of the microbial community associated with coral polyps and other marine organisms. Its presence and abundance may be influenced by environmental factors, such as water temperature, nutrient availability, and light conditions.

The taxonomy and phylogenetic relationships of Alterisphingorhabdus coralli are still being investigated, and it may be related to other haptophyte species found in marine environments.
